To make things more difficult, on my system (Kubuntu 9.04 Core 2 Duo) the timestamps keep changing. The JVM sends a key new release and new key press with the same timestamp. To detect when a user presses and releases a key in Java Swing, ignoring the keyboard auto repeat feature, you can use a Map to keep track of the key states. Here is an example implementation:

import java.awt.event.KeyEvent;
import java.awt.event.KeyListener;
import java.util.HashMap;
import java.util.Map;

public class Example implements KeyListener {
    private Map<Integer, Boolean> keyStates;

    public Example() {
        keyStates = new HashMap<>();
    }

    public void keyTyped(KeyEvent e) {}

    public void keyPressed(KeyEvent e) {
        int keyCode = e.getKeyCode();
        if (!keyStates.containsKey(keyCode) || !keyStates.get(keyCode)) {
            System.out.println("KeyPressed: " + keyCode);
            keyStates.put(keyCode, true);
        }
    }

    public void keyReleased(KeyEvent e) {
        int keyCode = e.getKeyCode();
        if (keyStates.containsKey(keyCode) && keyStates.get(keyCode)) {
            System.out.println("KeyReleased: " + keyCode);
            keyStates.put(keyCode, false);
        }
    }
}

In this code, we use a Map<Integer, Boolean> keyStates to keep track of the key states. When a key is pressed, we check if it is not already pressed (keyStates.containsKey(keyCode) && keyStates.get(keyCode)). If it is not, we print the "KeyPressed" message and update the key state in the map. Similarly, when a key is released, we check if it is currently pressed (keyStates.containsKey(keyCode) && keyStates.get(keyCode)). If it is, we print the "KeyReleased" message and update the key state in the map.

This approach ensures that we receive just one key press event for each key press and just one key release event for each key release, ignoring the keyboard auto repeat feature. Additionally, you can use the keyStates map to check if the user is holding more than one key at a time.

Note: This code assumes that you have already added the Example class as a KeyListener to your Swing component.
